{{italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Use British English|date=March 2014}} {{distinguish|text= the flower known as [[Belladonna lily|Naked Ladies]]}} [[File:The naked Ladies.jpg|thumb|250px|Frontal view, "topped by an Oceanid and two horses".]] {{coord|51|26|48.30|N|0|19|26.50|W|display=title}}
'''''The Naked Ladies''''' are a statue complex on a [[Rock garden|rockery]] and water cascade in the gardens of [[York House, Twickenham]], in the [[London Borough of Richmond upon Thames]], England. The larger than human size statues depict eight [[Oceanids]] and a pair of aquatic horses. They were carved in the [[fin de siècle]] style from white [[Carrara marble]] and probably came from Italy in the late nineteenth century or very early twentieth century. Originally they were part of a larger set of statues that was subdivided after the suicide of the initial purchaser.
After a somewhat unpromising start, they were installed in their current location without the benefit of the original design for their display. The statues spent several years as the backdrop for some of London's grandest garden parties. They subsequently passed by default into public ownership, and suffered some vandalism, but have been restored and remain to this day on view in the corner of a municipal garden.
== Design == [[File:Naked Ladies - view from the bridge.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Colour photograph, zoom shot through trees of two nude female statues on a rockery, one sitting, the other in a strange pose|The statues were installed without benefit of instruction from the designer as he spoke no English.]] [[File:Lady with Pearl.JPG|thumb|right|alt=Colour photograph, rear view of marble statue of lady holding a pearl.|Another suggested name for the statues was the Pearl Fishers, but today only one lady still has a pearl.]] [[File:York House statues 4 ladies detail.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Colour photograph of rockery from the side showing three ladies facing forward and up with their right hands raised|Side view of ladies in unusual poses]] The statues are of Italian design, and come from [[Carrara]]. They are of a monumental scale with several of the individual blocks weighing over {{convert|5|LT|t|sigfig=1|lk=on}}.<ref name="TM">{{cite web | title = The Statues at York House | url = http://www.twickenham-museum.org.uk/detail.asp?ContentID=11 | publisher = [[Twickenham Museum]] | accessdate = 3 July 2009}}</ref>
The sculptures were acquired during the disposal of the property of the original owner after his death. Due to the unusual circumstances of their acquisition they had become separated from any instructions as to their intended layout, and also from at least one other group of statues in what was originally intended to be a larger statue complex or complexes.
The rockery was designed and the whole complex installed by the British company of [[J Cheal & Sons]] who had to make their own interpretation as to the intended layout of the statues.<ref name="TM" /> Though they were able to incorporate all the statues into one tableaux, their interpretation of the sculptor's intended design has led to comments about the unusual poses of some of the statues, especially when viewed from the side.
Originally some of the ladies were holding pearls, but much of this detail has now been lost. There have been various theories as to the intended subject matter, with Pearl Fishers, [[Pegasus]], [[Naiads]] and [[The Birth of Venus (Botticelli)|the birth of Venus]] all having been suggested in addition to the usual attribution as [[Oceanides]]. For want of anything more official, they have become known as ''The Naked Ladies''.<ref name="HP">{{cite book | title = Twickenham Past | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=_wRHAAAACAAJ | isbn = 0-948667-22-2 | publisher = Historical Publications | year = 1993 | page = 139 | last1 = Simpson | first1 = Donald | first2 = Borough of Twickenham Local History Society | accessdate = 13 August 2009}}</ref>
== Setting == [[File:Vista York House gardens.jpg|thumb|alt=The colour photograph presents a series of lawns leading up to a statue complex. Hedges partially divide these lawns into three sections. The division closest to the camera contains flower beds, while the middle portion holds a circular pond – visible as a stone edge, the far lawn leads up to the statue complex.|''The Naked Ladies'' towering over the riverside lawns.]] The complex is in the gardens of York House by the banks of the [[River Thames]]. The gardens have been laid out in an Italian style to give unrestricted frontal views of the statue complex from the entire width of the gardens. The statues are set in a rockery behind a pond, with trees and security fencing restricting side and rear views.
== History == === Whitaker Wright === The statues were amongst the property of the celebrated fraudster [[Whitaker Wright]], who committed suicide by ingestion of a cyanide capsule upon being convicted of fraud. It is not certain where he acquired the statues, or who carved them. After his death much of his collection was sold from [[Witley Park]], including ''the Naked Ladies'' and also some mounted nymphs of a similar style, which went to [[Beale Park]]; one of the latter bore the mark "O SPALMACH, STUDIO O ANDREONI, ROMA."<ref name="TM2">{{cite web | last = Payan | first = J | title = The Statues in York House Gardens Twickenham | url = http://www.twickenham-museum.org.uk/paper.asp?PaperID=1 | date = 9 September 1995 | work = | publisher = Twickenham Museum | accessdate = 3 July 2009 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071028173654/http://www.twickenham-museum.org.uk/paper.asp?PaperID=1 | archivedate = 28 October 2007 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> identifying the studio of the Roman sculptor [[Orazio Andreoni]], so it is possible that they were all sculpted there by [[Oscar Spalmach]].
=== Sir Ratan Tata === The statues were acquired from Witley Park and brought to their current location by Sir [[Ratanji Dadabhoy Tata]].<ref name="TM" /> Sir Ratan had bought York House from the [[Philippe d'Orléans (1869-1926)|duc d'Orléans]] in 1906, and by the end of 1909 he had had the Riverside gardens redesigned in the Italian style and the statues installed.
Sir Ratan was for several years a noted host for London High Society, with [[George V of the United Kingdom|King George V]] among the guests at his garden parties.
=== Twickenham Council === The statues came into the ''de facto'' possession of [[Municipal Borough of Twickenham|Twickenham Council]] in 1924 when they purchased York House for their new town hall. The statues had been left behind by the previous owners, as they had been unable to find a buyer despite putting them up for auction.<ref name="TM2" />
=== Hiding the statues in the Blitz === In [[the Blitz]] during the Second World War, there was concern that moonlight reflecting on the statues would give a navigation mark to the [[Luftwaffe]]. So as part of London's [[Blackout (wartime)|Blackout]] measures the statues were covered with a "grey sludge".<ref name="TM2" />
=== Modern times === As a result of local government reorganisation in the 1960s Twickenham became part of the [[London Borough of Richmond upon Thames]], but the town hall remains at York House and the gardens continue to be open to the public. The statues have gone through at least one major restoration to remove graffiti and the wartime grey cement, and reverse the effects of vandalism by replacing lost fingers, pearls and even a hoof.<ref name="HP" /> In 1983 the statues were protected with a [[Grade II]] listing by English Heritage.<ref>[https://www.historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1250324 Historic England retrieved 24th Sept 2016]</ref>
== Society and culture == [[File:Statues on public view.JPG|right|thumb|alt=a grassy lawn in front of a statues complex several people sunbathe or sit in the midground facing in the background a group of white statues that are significantly larger than the people. In the foreground a black bird is walking away from the whole tableaux|The larger than life statues are now in a public park]] ''The Naked Ladies'' are one of the visitor attractions of Twickenham,<ref>[http://www.visitlondon.com/attractions/detail/19216 visit London] "Recurring event, A chance to see the statues of naked female figures, some in highly unusual attitudes, which adorn a cascade and pool in the riverside portion of the gardens" retrieved 3 July 2009</ref> have had a beer named after them,<ref>[http://www.ratebeer.com/beer/twickenham-naked-ladies/70004/ Twickenham Brewery – Naked Ladies] "Good body and luscious aroma. Inspired by the statues of water nymphs in York House gardens in Twickenham, known locally as the Naked Ladies." retrieved 3 July 2009</ref> and are a popular backdrop for wedding photos.
== Gallery == {{commonscat}} {{Gallery|align=center | title = | lines = 5 | width = 170 | height = 160 |File:Imploring lady.jpg|alt1=Colour photograph of an individual female statue with short tousled hair lying on a rock pedestal. Supporting herself on her left arm, her head is up and her right arm raised |Nobody bid for the statues in the 1922 auction |File:Naked Ladies - Profile view.jpg|Profile view of complex showing cascade and dappling effect of reflections from the pool on the horses' wings. |File:Pond and ladies.jpg|View of pond, with [[Nymphaeaceae|water lilies]] |File:Two ladies.jpg|alt4=Colour photograph of two nude female statues, one on top of a rock helping another climb up it |One lady helping another out of the pond {{small|(the arm of the upper lady is carved as part of the lower sculpture)}} |File:'Naked Lady' Statue.jpg|One of the Ladies reaching out for something, in front of part of the water cascade. }}
==See also== * [[List of public art in Richmond upon Thames]] *[[Twickenham Fine Ales]]

{{italic title}} [[Image:passover plot.JPG|thumb|First edition (publ. [[Hutchinson (publisher)|Hutchinson]])]]
'''''The Passover Plot''''' is a 1965 [[conspiracy theory]] book <ref>{{cite book |last=Schonfield |first=Hugh Joseph |authorlink=Hugh J. Schonfield |title=The Passover Plot: a New Interpretation of the Life and Death of Jesus |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rrhk5B3AQocC |format=snippets view |accessdate= |year=1965 |edition=1996 reprint |publisher=Element |location= |isbn=9781852308360 |page=}}</ref> by British [[Bible|biblical]] scholar [[Hugh J. Schonfield]], who also published a translation of the [[New Testament]] with a Jewish perspective.<ref>[http://tyndalearchive.com/scriptures/ONT.htm ''The Original New Testament''] (originally published in 1958 as ''The Authentic New Testament'', updated and re-published under this title in 1985)</ref> The book was adapted into a film, ''[[The Passover Plot (film)|The Passover Plot]]'' (1976).
==Schonfield's conclusions== Based on his research into the social and religious culture in which [[Jesus]] was born, lived and died, and into other literature, including the source documents of the [[Gospel]]s, Schonfield reached the following conclusions: * That Jesus was a deeply religious [[Jew]]ish man, probably well-versed in the teachings of the local northern sects such as the [[Nazarene (sect)|Nazarene]]s and [[Essenes]]. * That growing up in biblical [[Galilee]] he had a skeptical and somewhat rebellious relationship to the hierarchy and teachings mandated by the authorities (the [[Saducee]]s) of the [[Temple in Jerusalem|Temple]] in [[Jerusalem]]. * That Jewish [[Messiah|Messianic]] expectation was extremely high in those times, matched to the despair caused by the [[Roman Empire|Roman]] occupation of the land and subjugation of the Jews. * That he was in many ways both typical of [[History of ancient Israel and Judah|his times]], and yet extraordinary in his religious convictions and beliefs, in his scholarship of the biblical literature, and in the fervency in which he lived his religion out in his daily life. * That he was convinced of his role as the expected Messiah based on the authority of his having been descendant from [[David|King David]] (the [[Davidic line|royal bloodline of David]]), and that he consciously and methodically, to the point of being calculating, attempted to fulfill that role, being eminently well-versed in the details of what that role entailed. * That he was convinced of the importance of his fulfilling the role perfectly (after all prophesy and expectation), and that he could not allow himself to fail, as that would undoubtedly lead to his being declared a [[False messiah|false Messiah]]. * That he was perfectly aware of the consequences of his actions all along the way, and that he directed his closest supporters, the original twelve [[Apostles]], unknowingly to aid him in his plans. * That he involved the least possible number of supporters in his plans ("[[need to know]]" basis), therefore very few knew of the details of his final plan, and even then only the least amount of information necessary.<ref name="Schaefer2003">{{cite book|author=Henry F. Schaefer|title=Science and Christianity: Conflict Or Coherence?|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g67eEE-t5TIC&pg=PA164|accessdate=4 November 2012|date=1 July 2003|publisher=The Apollos Trust|isbn=978-0-9742975-0-7|pages=164–}}</ref>
The culmination of his plan was to be his death (the [[crucifixion]]), his [[resurrection]] and his reign as the true kingly and priestly messiah, not in heaven but on earth—the realized king of the Jews.
==Planning== According to Schonfield's analysis, the events of the Passover, which are presented in all the Gospels, but inconsistently, are most accurately presented in the Gospel of John. His reading of that Gospel convinced him that John's account, though probably filtered through an assistant and transcription in John's old age, suggests that Jesus had planned everything. Among other things, so that he would not be on the cross for more than a few hours before the [[Shabbat|Sabbath]] arrived when it was required by law that Jews be taken down, so that one of his supporters, who was on hand, would give him water (to quench his thirst) that was actually laced with a drug to make him unconscious, and so that [[Joseph of Arimathea]], a well-connected supporter, would collect him off the cross while still alive (but appearing dead) so that he could be secretly nursed back to health. Schonfield suggests that the plan went awry because of a soldier's actions with a spear. Schonfield gives evidence of a high-ranking member of the Sanhedrin who was one of Jesus' followers, likely the [[Beloved Disciple]] who is otherwise obscure, and notes several instances in which knowledge of or access to the Temple was available to one or more of Jesus' followers. He identifies this follower as John, the source of the Gospel many decades later whilst living in Asia Minor. He suggests that this Apostle, and Joseph of Arimathea, were responsible for events following the Crucifixion, and that it might have been this Apostle (an 'undercover Disciple', as it were) who was seen (by those who did not know him) at the Tomb on the morning of the Resurrection.<ref name="Habermas1996">{{cite book|author=Gary R. Habermas|title=The Historical Jesus: Ancient Evidence for the Life of Christ|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pMMeqKHZIDkC&pg=PA70|accessdate=4 November 2012|date=1 June 1996|publisher=College Press|isbn=978-0-89900-732-8|pages=70–}}</ref>
==Second half of the book== After first laying out the storyline and outcome of Jesus' life in the first half of the book, along with supportive arguments, Schonfield devotes the second half of the book to a more detailed explanation of the concepts and arguments used to support his conclusions. Schonfield also discusses how Jesus' original message and purpose may have become transformed during the century after his death.
==Film based on book== {{Main article|The Passover Plot (film)}} ''[[The Passover Plot (film)|The Passover Plot]]'' is the name of a 1976 film which was adapted from this book. The movie starred [[Zalman King]] as ''Yeshua'' ([[Jesus]]), and the cast included [[Harry Andrews]], [[Dan Hedaya]], and [[Donald Pleasence]]. It was directed by [[Michael Campus]] and nominated for an [[Academy Awards|Oscar]] for Best Costume Design. Schonfield also featured in the dramatised documentary television series, ''Jesus: The Evidence'' (1984: LWT for Channel 4).
==See also== * [[Jesuism]]

{{Use Irish English|date=March 2017}} This is a '''timeline of actions by the [[Real Irish Republican Army]]''', also called the '''Real IRA''', an [[Irish republicanism|Irish republican]] [[paramilitary]] group. The group was formed in late 1997 by members of the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army]] who disagreed with that organisation's ceasefire.
The Real IRA is the largest and most active of the [[dissident republican]] paramilitaries [[Dissident Irish Republican campaign|waging a campaign against]] the British security forces. The other main republican paramilitary groups are the [[Óglaigh na hÉireann (Real IRA splinter group)|group which calls itself Óglaigh na hÉireann]], the [[Continuity IRA]] and [[Arm na Poblachta]] the newest group. All actions listed took place in [[Northern Ireland]] unless stated otherwise.
{{TOC right}}
==1998== ''Note: for some of the incidents in 1998, it is unclear whether the Real IRA, the [[Continuity Irish Republican Army|Continuity IRA]], or both organisations were responsible.''<ref name="CAIN 98">{{cite web|title=Chronology of the Conflict: 1998|author=CAIN|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/othelem/chron/ch98.htm|publisher=CAIN|accessdate=10 June 2009}}</ref><ref name="org-cira">{{cite web|title=Organizations: C|url=http://www.cain.ulst.ac.uk/othelem/organ/corgan.htm|publisher=CAIN.ulst.ac.uk|accessdate=31 March 2010}}</ref><ref name="org-rira">{{cite web|title=Organizations: R|url=http://www.cain.ulst.ac.uk/othelem/organ/rorgan.htm|publisher=CAIN.ulst.ac.uk|accessdate=31 March 2010}}</ref>
*6 January: A 500 lb car bomb was defused by the security forces in the centre of [[Banbridge]], [[County Down]]. A telephoned warning had been sent.<ref name="CAIN 98"/> *20 February: Following a telephoned warning, a 500 lb car bomb exploded outside the [[Royal Ulster Constabulary]] (RUC) base in [[Moira, County Down]]. Seven RUC officers and four civilians were hurt. The blast caused widespread damage.<ref>{{cite news|title=Eleven injured by Northern Ireland bomb|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/58729.stm|publisher=BBC|date=21 February 1998|accessdate=8 May 2007}}</ref> *23 February: Following a telephoned warning, a 300 lb car bomb exploded near the RUC base on Edward Street in [[Portadown]], [[County Armagh]]. The blast caused widespread damage but no injuries.<ref name="republican-news.org">{{cite web|url=http://republican-news.org/archive/1998/February26/26bomb.html |title=AN PHOBLACHT/REPUBLICAN NEWS |publisher= |accessdate=22 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120927010336/http://republican-news.org/archive/1998/February26/26bomb.html |archivedate=27 September 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Car bomb explodes in Portadown|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/59314.stm|publisher=BBC|date=23 February 1998|accessdate=8 May 2007}}</ref> *10 March: There was a [[barrack buster]] attack on the RUC base on Newry Road in [[Armagh]]. Five mortars were launched and three exploded on impact.<ref name=nally>[http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/events/omagh/docs/nally0603.pdf Nally Report (2003)]. pp.9-12</ref> People were evacuated from the surrounding area after the [[British Army]] spotted the launchers, and there were no injuries.<ref name="CAIN 98"/> *24 March: There were two mortar attacks in South Armagh. Four mortars were fired at [[Forkill]] British Army/RUC base; one exploded inside the base but caused no injuries. A further two mortars were fired at a British Army watchtower at Glasdrumman, but fell short of the target.<ref name=hoey>[http://www.bailii.org/nie/cases/NICC/2007/49.html The Queen -v- Sean Hoey [2007] NICC 49]. Crown Court for Northern Ireland.</ref> It is believed the RIRA was responsible.<ref name=nally/> *30 April: Following a telephoned warning, a 550–600 lb car bomb was defused in the centre of [[Lisburn]].<ref name=hoey/> It is believed the RIRA was responsible.<ref name=nally/> *1 May: RIRA member Ronan Mac Lochlainn, a native of [[County Dublin]], was shot dead by [[Gardaí]] during an attempted robbery of a cash-in-transit van in [[County Wicklow]], [[Republic of Ireland]].<ref name="CAIN 98"/> *4 May: There was an attempted mortar attack on Grosvenor Road RUC base in [[Belfast]]. One of the mortars fell short of the target and the other exploded in its launch tube.<ref name="CAIN 98"/> *8 May: The RIRA issued a statement declaring war on the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name="CAIN 98"/> *9 May: There was an attempted mortar attack on the RUC base in [[Belleek, County Fermanagh|Belleek]], [[County Fermanagh]]. The mortars fell short of the target and one exploded as the RUC was clearing the area. A claim of responsibility was made on behalf of the Real IRA.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/real-ira-admits-bid-to-bomb-police-station-444962.html|work=Irish Independent|first=John|last=Hicks|title='Real IRA' admits bid to bomb police station|date=11 May 1998}}</ref> *16 May: Following a telephoned warning, a 500 lb car bomb was defused near the RUC base in Armagh.<ref name=hoey/> *23 June: The RIRA is believed to have been responsible for an explosion on a road near Forkill, County Armagh.<ref name="CAIN 98"/> *13 July: Following a telephoned warning, a 635 lb car bomb was defused outside the courthouse in [[Newry]].<ref name=hoey/> It is believed the RIRA was responsible.<ref name=nally/> *21 July: A mortar was fired at Corry Square RUC base in Newry, but fell short of the target and did not detonate.<ref name=hoey/> The Real IRA claimed responsibility.<ref name="CAIN 98"/> *28 July: The RIRA was blamed for planting incendiary bombs in shops in Portadown.<ref name="org-rira"/> *1 August: [[1998 Banbridge bombing]]: A 500 lb car bomb exploded in the centre of Banbridge, County Down. Telephoned warnings were sent but the bomb exploded before the area was fully evacuated. Two RUC officers and thirty-three civilians were hurt and the blast caused extensive damage.<ref name=hoey/> The Real IRA claimed responsibility.<ref name="CAIN 98"/> *15 August: [[Omagh bombing]]: A 500 lb car bomb exploded in the centre of [[Omagh]], [[County Tyrone]]. The bomb killed 29 civilians and wounded 220 others. This was the highest death toll from a single attack during the Troubles. Although warnings had been given 38 minutes beforehand, they proved to be insufficient.<ref name="CAIN 98"/> *18 August: The RIRA announced it was suspending all military operations.<ref name="CAIN 98"/> *7 September: The RIRA announced a ceasefire.<ref name="CAIN 98"/>
==1999== *9 May: A 2007 inquest heard that the RIRA were responsible for the killing of Brendan "Speedy" Fegan in [[Newry]], [[County Down]] as a purported drug dealer.<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/7038586.stm|title=Drug dealing was 'behind murder'|date=10 October 2007|publisher=BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/339606.stm|title=Gunmen kill 'top drug dealer'|date=10 May 1999|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
==2000== *20 January: The RIRA announced an end to its ceasefire.<ref>{{cite news|title=Real IRA call for unity among all Republicans|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2000/0120/north.html|publisher=RTÉ|date=20 January 2000|accessdate=15 June 2007}}</ref> *25 February: The RIRA is believed to have been responsible for a bomb attack against a British Army barracks in [[Ballykelly, County Londonderry]]. The [[Continuity IRA]] (CIRA) initially claimed responsibility for the blast but security sources said they believed it was the RIRA who were responsible.<ref>{{cite news|title=Real IRA behind bid to blow up barracks|author=Tom Brady|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/real-ira-behind-bid-to-blow-up-barracks-383691.html|publisher=Independent.ie|date=29 February 2000|accessdate=15 June 2007}}</ref> *6 April: The RIRA detonated a bomb at Ebrington British Army barracks in [[Derry]]. The bomb destroyed an unmanned guardhouse and damaged the perimeter fence.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bombing blamed on dissidents|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/703814.stm|publisher=BBC|date=6 April 2000|accessdate=15 June 2007}}</ref> *14 April: The RIRA were blamed for a failed mortar bomb attack on an army base in [[Rosslea]], County Fermanagh.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Real+IRA+blamed+for+attack+on+RUC+base.-a061485730|title=Real IRA blamed for attack on RUC was on a railway line at [[Ealing Broadway]] in London.<ref name=MirrorTimeline/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/841461.stm|title=Bomb found on tube line|publisher=BBC News|date=19 July 2000}}</ref> *20 June: The RIRA were responsible for a leaving an explosive device in the property of former Northern Ireland Secretary of State [[Peter Mandelson]] in [[Hillsborough, County Down]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/798309.stm|title=Mandelson feels 'safe' despite device|date=20 June 2000|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> *30 June: The RIRA bombed the main Dublin-to-Belfast railway line near [[Meigh]], County Armagh.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dissidents linked to railway blast|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/812563.stm|publisher=BBC|date=30 June 2000|accessdate=28 June 2007}}</ref> *9 July: The RIRA detonated a car bomb at [[Stewartstown, County Tyrone]] RUC station.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dissidents linked to NI blast|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/825178.stm|publisher=BBC|date=9 July 2000|accessdate=28 June 2007}}</ref> *12 Both bombs failed to detonate and were later defused by British Army bomb disposal experts.<ref name=MirrorTimeline/><ref>{{cite for a mortar bomb attack on an RUC station in [[Armagh]] town.<ref name=MirrorTimeline/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/922948.stm|title=Bomb attack on police planted in a wooden hut and partially exploded when a soldier opened the door to the hut.<ref name="rcni2">Mooney & O'Toole, pp. 347-348.</ref> The second bomb was found during a follow-up search and ==2001== *23 January: The RIRA were responsible for a mortar attack on [[Ebrington Barracks]] in [[Derry]]. One mortar landed inside the perimeter fence of the base after being fired from a parked van. No one was injured.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2001/0123/bomb.html|title=Dissident Republicans blamed for mortar attack|publisher=RTÉ|date=23 January 2001}}</ref> *5 February: The RIRA were responsible for a pipe bomb attack in which a couple were injured in [[Newcastle, County Down]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/1153132.stm Couple injured by pipe bomb], bbc.co.uk; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref> The RIRA would later kill the man, in a gun attack a year later in February 2002.<ref name="http">{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/man-gunned-down-in--car-ambush-after--personal-feud-13676050.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130419203402/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/man-gunned-down-in--car-ambush-after--personal-feud-13676050.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-04-19 |title=Man gunned down in car ambush after personal feud }}</ref> *21 February: A RIRA bomb disguised as a [[flashlight|torch]] exploded outside a British Army barracks in [[Shepherd's Bush]], West London, after a 14-year-old [[Army Cadet Force|army cadet]] picked it up. The cadet, Stephen Menary, lost his left hand and left eye, and suffered severe stomach and chest injuries.<ref>{{cite news|title=TA blast was deliberate attack|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1183106.stm|publisher=BBC|date=22 February 2001|accessdate=15 June 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=BBC bomb prompts terror warning|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1201444.stm|publisher=BBC|date=5 March 2001|accessdate=16 June 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Sarah Hall |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2001/apr/04/sarahhall |title=Bomb blast cadet tells of ordeal | UK news |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date= |accessdate=2016-12-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-532530/Bombed-cadet-blindness-payout-halved--lost-eye-cancer.html |title=Bombed cadet has blindness payout halved - because he had already lost an eye to cancer |website=Dailymail.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-12-24}}</ref> *4 March: The RIRA detonated a car bomb outside the [[BBC]]'s London headquarters (see [[4 March 2001 BBC bombing]]).<ref>{{cite news|title=Bomb blast outside BBC|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1201273.stm|publisher=BBC|date=4 March 2001|accessdate=3 May 2007}}</ref> The explosion was captured by a BBC cameraman and the footage was broadcast on TV stations worldwide, gaining mass publicity for the group.<ref>{{cite book|last=Taylor|first=Peter|authorlink=Peter Taylor (journalist)|title=Brits|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|year=2001|page=384|isbn=0-7475-5806-X}}</ref> *14 April: The RIRA was blamed for a small bomb explosion at a postal sorting office in [[Hendon]], London. No one was injured in the explosion, which caused "minor" damage to the building at The Hyde, in Hendon.<ref>{{cite news|title=Real IRA linked to post office blast|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1278355.stm|publisher=BBC|date=15 April 2001|accessdate=15 June 2007}}</ref> *23 April: The RIRA were blamed for a grenade attack on an RUC station in [[Derry]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/ruc-base-target-of-grenade--attack-as-real-ira-strike-13852557.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120802010657/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/ruc-base-target-of-grenade--attack-as-real-ira-strike-13852557.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 August 2012 |title=RUC base target of grenade attack as Real IRA strike |date=23 April 2001 |author=Ciaran O'Neill |work=Belfast Telegraph }}</ref> *6 May: The RIRA was blamed for a small bomb explosion at the same [[Hendon]] building where another bomb had exploded on 14 April 2001. There was no warning and one man was injured in the explosion.<ref name="CAIN 01">{{cite web|title=Chronology of the Conflict|author=CAIN|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/othelem/chron/ch01.htm|publisher=CAIN|accessdate=27 February 2010}}</ref> *15 May: The RIRA was blamed for a mortar attack on an army base in [[Bessbrook|Bessbrook, County Armagh]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/1333058.stm|title=Suspected attack on army base|date=15 May 2001|publisher=BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/sinn-fein-anger-over-bomb-13838168.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120722033446/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/sinn-fein-anger-over-bomb-13838168.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=22 July 2012 |title=Sinn Féin anger over bomb |author=Smyth Harper |date=17 May 2001 |work=Belfast Telegraph }}</ref> *May 27: The RIRA were responsible for a failed rocket attack on an RUC station in [[Strabane|Strabane, County Tyrone]]. The device contained just over one pound of [[Semtex]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://archives.tcm.ie/irishexaminer/2001/05/28/story4098.asp |title=Real IRA blamed for rocket attack on RUC station |author=Joe Oliver |work=Irish Examiner |date=28 May 2001 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050515004833/http://archives.tcm.ie/irishexaminer/2001/05/28/story4098.asp |archivedate=15 May 2005 |df= }}</ref> *8 June: The RIRA was blamed for a gun attack at a polling station in [[Draperstown|Draperstown, County Londonderry]]. Two RUC officers and a civilian were wounded.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/police-facing-fresh-terror-threat-13799565.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120722094101/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/police-facing-fresh-terror-threat-13799565.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=22 July 2012 |title=Police facing fresh terror threat |author=Darwin Templeton |date=8 June 2001 |work=Belfast Telegraph }}</ref> *1 August: The RIRA planted a 44 lb car bomb at [[Belfast International Airport]]. It was made safe by bomb disposal officers.<ref name="CAIN 01"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/bomb-fuels-demands-to-step-up-security-at-aldergrove-13783243.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120719072829/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/bomb-fuels-demands-to-step-up-security-at-aldergrove-13783243.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 July 2012 |title=Bomb fuels demands to step up security at Aldergrove |author=Darwin Templeton |date=2 August 2001 |work=Belfast Telegraph }}</ref> *3 August: The RIRA detonated a car bomb in [[Ealing]], London, injuring seven people (see [[3 August 2001 Ealing bombing]]).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/2930957.stm|title=Real IRA bombers jailed|date=9 April 2003|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> *22 August: The RIRA planted a small bomb on a bridge in [[Derry]]. The group gave a telephoned warning and the bomb was defused.<ref name="CAIN 01"/> *1 November: The RIRA were blamed for planting a faulty incendiary device in a sports shop in Hill Street, [[Newry]], [[County Down]].{{Why|date=November 2015}} The device was smouldering in a pocket of the jacket, but had burnt itself out.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/1669326.stm|title=Device explodes in shop|date=22 November 2001|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> *3 November: The RIRA planted a car bomb in the centre of [[Birmingham]], England but it failed to detonate properly.<ref>{{cite news|title=New leads in hunt for bombers|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/1649338.stm|publisher=BBC|date=11 November 2001|accessdate=3 May 2007}}</ref>
==2002== *3 January: The RIRA carried out a pipe bomb attack on a police officer's home in [[Annalong]], [[County Down]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/1742240.stm|work=BBC News|title=Republicans 'attacked officer's home'|date=4 January 2002|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref><ref>[http://archives.tcm.ie/downdemocrat/2002/01/07/story185.asp ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629111458/http://archives.tcm.ie/downdemocrat/2002/01/07/story185.asp |date=June 29, 2011 }}</ref> *26 January: The RIRA were believed to have been responsible for a blast bomb attack during disturbances in north [[Belfast]]. Three police officers and two soldiers were injured in the blast.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/1783590.stm 2 soldiers and 3 police officers hurt in Belfast blast], bbc.co.uk; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref><ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4161/is_20020127/ai_n9710226/pg_2/?tag=content;col1 'Real IRA' planned ambush] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111118011811/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4161/is_20020127/ai_n9710226/pg_2/?tag=content%3Bcol1 |date=2011-11-18 }}, findarticles.com, 27 January 2002.</ref> *21 February: The RIRA claimed responsibility for the shooting death of Matthew Burns in a car outside [[Castlewellan]], [[County Down]]. Burns' brother, the driver, was injured. It is believed the killing was a result of a personal feud between Burns and the RIRA.<ref name="http"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/1835993.stm|work=BBC News|title=Republicans linked to murder|date=22 February 2002|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref> *3 March: Two teenaged boys are injured with a RIRA booby trap bomb in [[Forkill|Forkill, County Armagh]]. The device was hidden inside a traffic cone when it exploded.<ref name=MirrorBomb/><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/1852162.stm Boys injured in Forkill, County Armagh blast], bbc.co.uk; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref> *29 March: The RIRA targeted a former member of the [[Royal Irish Regiment (1992)|Royal Irish Regiment]] in [[Sion Mills]], [[County Tyrone]]. A bomb was attached to his car but failed to explode.<ref>[http://www.independent.ie/national-news/exsoldier-escapes-real--ira-booby-trap-bomb--attack-315371.html Ex-soldier escapes 'Real IRA' booby trap bomb attack], independent.ie; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref> *13 April: The RIRA were blamed for two bomb attacks on [[Police Service of Northern Ireland|PSNI]] stations in [[Downpatrick]] and [[Ardglass]], both in [[County Down]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/1927657.stm Dissidents blamed for bomb attacks], bbc.co.uk; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/corruption-brings-down--terror-group-504431.html|work=Irish Independent|first=Liz|last=Walsh|title=Corruption brings down terror group|date=20 October 2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/renegade-rira-gang-in-new-terror-campaign-13638627.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120729032959/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/renegade-rira-gang-in-new-terror-campaign-13638627.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=29 July 2012 |title=RIRA gang in new terror campaign |accessdate=10 October 2015 }}</ref> *5 June: The RIRA are believed to have been linked to a kidnapping in [[Ballyhornan]], [[County Down]].<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2002/jun/02/northernireland Real IRA man held over kidnap], guardian.co.uk, 2 June 2002.</ref> *17 July: The RIRA claimed responsibility for an attack on a [[Police Service of Northern Ireland]] (PSNI) patrol car in [[Downpatrick]], [[County Down]]. An explosive device was fired at the car but bounced off and failed to explode.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/2133624.stm|work=BBC News|title=Dissidents admit bomb attack|date=17 July 2002|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-89200102.html|title=Weapon was tested during winter|date=18 July 2002|work=The Belfast News Letter}}{{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}</ref> *2 August: The RIRA was blamed for detonating a bomb at a British Territorial Army base in [[Derry]]. A civilian builder was killed in the blast.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/2166312.stm|work=BBC News|title=Dissidents blamed for army attack|date=1 August 2002|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2002/aug/02/northernireland.rosiecowan|work=The Guardian|location=London, UK|title=Real IRA blamed as bomb kills civilian at Territorial Army base|first=Rosie|last=Cowan|date=2 August 2002|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref> *20 October: The RIRA claimed responsibility for an attempted bombing of the PSNI station in [[Castlederg]], [[County Tyrone]]. A coffee jar bomb packed with shrapnel was thrown over the perimeter fence but failed to explode.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/2344579.stm|work=BBC News|title=Real IRA 'to respond to prisoners'|date=20 October 2002|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/2344531.stm|work=BBC News|title=Bomb thrown at police station|date=20 October 2002|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref> *24 November: The RIRA were believed to have been responsible for an attempted bombing of a motor tax office in [[Belfast]]. The operation was intercepted by undercover police and one of the bombers was severely injured after police fired a number of shots. Two men were arrested at the scene.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/2509513.stm|title=Man critical after security operation|date=25 November 2002|work=BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/8416588.stm|title=Jail recall man was 'RIRA chief'|date=16 December 2009|work=BBC News|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref>
==2003== *13 March: The RIRA left a bomb in a van outside Laganside Courthouse in [[Belfast]]. It was defused by bomb disposal officers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/2846019.stm|work=BBC News|title=Real IRA admits court bomb|date=13 March 2003|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref> *5 April: The RIRA claimed it had sent an incendiary bomb to Maghaberry prison. The bomb was defused by the British army.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-99655796.html|title=Real IRA claims it sent bomb to Maghaberry|date=5 April 2003|work=The Belfast News Letter|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> *5 May: The RIRA were responsible for an attempting bombing of a motor tax office in [[Belfast]]. The device, which was in a van parked outside the motor tax office in Upper Queen Street, contained three pipe bombs and three fuel containers.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/low/northern_ireland/3001037.stm "Dissident republicans behind bomb"], bbc.co.uk; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref> *19 June: The RIRA abandoned a 1,200 lb van bomb on the outskirts of [[Derry]]. The device was described as "one of the biggest ever found in the UK".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/2991676.stm|work=BBC News|title=Huge van bomb intercepted|date=15 June 2003|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/real-ira-claims-responsibility-for-derry-van-bomb-13648576.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120802164207/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/real-ira-claims-responsibility-for-derry-van-bomb-13648576.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 August 2012 |title=RIRA claims responsibility for Derry van bomb |accessdate=10 October 2015 }}</ref> *17 August: The RIRA killed Danny McGurk, a civilian, on the Ross Road, Lower Falls, [[Belfast|West Belfast]]. The RIRA later issued a statement that McGurk had been an "innocent civilian" and offered its "sincere condolences" to his family and friends, adding that the killing was "criminally wrong and detracted from the goal of Irish liberation". McGurk had reportedly had a pub dispute with members of the RIRA, and been beaten by members of the group a week before his killing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nuzhound.com/articles/irish_news/arts2007/jun13_RIRA_McGurk_murder.php|title=Newshound: Daily Northern Ireland news catalog: Danny McGurk murder|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> *3 September: The RIRA were blamed for leaving a roadside bomb near [[Bryansford]], [[County Down]]. It was believed to have been meant for a passing PSNI patrol.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/3192247.stm|work=BBC News|title=Device targeted at PSNI officers|date=30 August 2003|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref><ref>[http://archives.tcm.ie/downdemocrat/2003/09/03/story1374.asp ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629110722/http://archives.tcm.ie/downdemocrat/2003/09/03/story1374.asp |date=June 29, 2011 }}</ref> *21 September: The RIRA were blamed for firing a number of shots near the home of [[Social Democratic and Labour Party]] councilor Peter Fitzpatrick in [[Kilcoo, County Down]]. Fitzpatrick had recently denounced the group and its actions.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/rira-mount-new-intimidation-war-13644203.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120728172336/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/rira-mount-new-intimidation-war-13644203.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=28 July 2012 |title=RIRA mount new intimidation war |accessdate=10 October 2015 }}</ref> *12 October: The RIRA were responsible for an attempted bombing of a PSNI station in [[Rosslea]], [[County Fermanagh]]. A 130 lb car bomb was defused by the British Army.<ref>[http://www.rte.ie/news/2003/1012/rosslea.html Car bomb defused in County Fermanagh], rte.ie; 12 October 2003.</ref> *20 November: The RIRA attempted to ambush PSNI and British Army members in [[Newcastle, County Down]]. The group claimed there was a bomb at the empty Enniskeen Hotel. However, this was a hoax meant to draw the police and army towards the real bomb. The time bomb was found and made safe.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/3283063.stm|work=BBC News|title=Dissidents attempt 'police trap'|date=19 November 2003|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2003/nov/20/northernireland.rosiecowan|work=The Guardian|location=London, UK|title=Police foil Real IRA bombing|first=Rosie|last=Cowan|date=20 November 2003|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2003/1119/bomb.html|work=RTÉ News|title=Real IRA left Co Down bomb, says PSNI|date=19 November 2003|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref>
==2004== *4 February: The RIRA claimed responsibility for planting a bomb inside a British Army base at [[Ballykelly, County Londonderry]]. It failed to explode.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2004/0204/realira.html|work=RTÉ News|title=Real IRA says it planted bomb in Co Derry|date=4 February 2004}}</ref> *26 March: Four men were charged with RIRA membership after involvement in a RIRA firebomb attack on a house in [[Cork (city)|Cork City, County Cork]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2004/0326/realira.html|work=RTÉ News|title=Four charged over alleged Real IRA attack|date=26 March 2004}}</ref> *8 May: The RIRA were responsible for sending packages containing a number of bullets and a sympathy card to elected representatives on Newry & Mourne District Council. The packages were addressed to the District Policing Partnership members at SDLP premises and council offices in [[Newry]], [[County Down]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/3695965.stm Bullets sent to SDLP councillors], bbc.co.uk; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref> *8 September: The RIRA claimed responsibility for a gun attack on Strand Road PSNI station in [[Derry]]. No one was injured but builders who were working on an extension in the fortified base had to dive for cover as the gunman opened fire.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/AK-47+TERROR%3b+Real+IRA+riddles+cars+in+attack+on+police+base.-a0121744101|title=AK-47 TERROR; Real IRA riddles cars in attack on police base.|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> *30 September: The RIRA were responsible for sending a parcel bomb to an SDLP councillor, Eamonn O'Neill in [[Castlewellan]], [[County Down]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-122663844.html|title=Parcel Bomb Sent to SDLP Councillor|last=Bradfield|first=Philip|work=The News Letter|date=30 September 2004}}{{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/real-ira-mole-hunt-after-attack-thwarted-13680998.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120729025133/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/imported/real-ira-mole-hunt-after-attack-thwarted-13680998.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-29 |title=Real IRA mole hunt after attack thwarted |publisher=BelfastTelegraph.co.uk |date=2004-10-24 |accessdate=2015-10-10 }}</ref> *24 November: The RIRA carried out a firebomb attack on a commercial premises in [[Belfast]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Firebomb campaign hits Belfast|author=Angelique Chrisafis|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk_news/story/0,,1360118,00.html|publisher=''The Guardian''|date=26 November 2004|accessdate=3 May 2007|location=London, UK}}</ref>
==2005== *6 November: The RIRA were blamed for a hoax bomb alert at the [[Down Royal]] Racecourse in [[County Down]]. The bomb warning disrupted a two-day racing festival in which 9,000 racegoers had to be evacuated.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2005/nov/06/northernireland.northernireland1|work=The Guardian|location=London, UK|title=Real IRA blamed as race festival is wrecked|first=Henry|last=McDonald|date=6 November 2005|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref>
==2006== *9 August: The RIRA carried out a number of firebomb attacks on businesses in [[Newry]], [[County Down]]. Buildings belonging to [[JJB Sports]] and [[Carpetright]] were destroyed, and ones belonging to [[MFI Retail|MFI]] and [[TK Maxx]] were badly damaged.<ref>{{cite news| title=Real IRA admits city bomb attacks|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/4783953.stm|publisher=BBC|date=11 August 2006|accessdate=3 May 2007}}</ref> *13 August: The RIRA claimed it left two devices on the Belfast–Dublin railway line in south [[County Armagh]], between [[Newry]] and [[Dundalk]]. The alert caused massive disruption to railway and road traffic in the area.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/4788045.stm |title=UK | Northern Ireland | Bomb alerts hit transport system |publisher=BBC News |date=2006-08-13 |accessdate=2015-10-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-149436485.html|title=Real IRA alert hits road & rail.(News)|author=<!-- Staff -->|work=[[The Daily Mirror]]|date=2006-08-14|accessdate=2014-07-02}}{{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}</ref> *16 August: The RIRA were blamed for an attempted bombing on the home of an [[Ulster Unionist]] Peer, [[Lord Ballyedmond]] in [[County Louth]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/4797095.stm |title=UK | Northern Ireland | Bomb defused at UUP peer's house |publisher=BBC News |date=2006-08-16 |accessdate=2015-10-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-149576555.html|title=Tycoon in bomb attack|first=Brian|last=Hutton|date=17 August 2006|work=The Daily Mirror; London (UK)}}{{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}</ref> *8 September: The RIRA were blamed for a hoax bomb threat against a DPP meeting in [[Downpatrick]], [[County Down]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-151178837.html|title=DPP meeting bomb scare|year=2006|work=The News Letter (Belfast, Northern Ireland)}}{{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}</ref> *1 November: The RIRA were responsible for a number of fire bomb attacks on businesses in [[Belfast]]. Businesses such as [[Homebase]], [[Smyths]] & [[JJB Sports]] were badly damaged.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/6105290.stm|work=BBC News|title=Dissidents 'behind bomb attacks'|date=1 November 2006|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref> *4 December: The RIRA are believed to have been responsible for a failed mortar attack on a PSNI Station in [[Craigavon]], [[County Armagh]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Device is fired at police station|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/6206266.stm|publisher=BBC|date=4 December 2006|accessdate=6 May 2007}}</ref><ref name="IMC15">{{cite journal|last=Independent Monitoring Commission |title=Fifteenth report of the Independent Monitoring Commission |page=12 |date=25 April 2007 |publisher=The Stationery Office |url=http://www.independentmonitoringcommission.org/documents/uploads/ACFAAB.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=6 May 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070615143915/http://www.independentmonitoringcommission.org/documents/uploads/ACFAAB.pdf |archivedate=15 June 2007 |df= }}</ref>
==2007== *18 July: The RIRA claimed responsibility for the discovery of two bombs during a security alert in [[Newry]], [[County Down]]. One of the devices exploded, while army experts carried out a controlled explosion on the other. It was claimed in a statement that the bombs were intended for use against members of the PSNI.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/6905134.stm|title=Northern Ireland | Devices 'had potential to kill'|publisher=BBC News|date=18 July 2007|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://southarmagh32.blogspot.com/2007/08/ira-claim-double-bomb-attack.html|title=South Armagh 32 County Sovereignty Movement: I.R.A. claim double bomb attack|publisher=Southarmagh32.blogspot.com|date=23 August 2007|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref> *25 August: The RIRA carried out a gun attack on the home of a former SDLP councillor, Pat Bradley, in [[Derry]].<!-- results?? -->{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} *10 October: An inquest heard about the murder of Brendan "Speedy" Fegan in [[Newry]], [[County Down]] in 1999. It is believed Fegan was killed by the RIRA as a result of his alleged drug dealing activities.<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk"/> *8 November: A PSNI officer was shot and wounded by the RIRA as he sat in his car on Bishop Street, [[Derry]].<ref name="BBC-PSNI-1211">{{cite news|title= Policeman injured in gun attack|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/7091544.stm|work=BBC News|date=12 November 2007|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref> *12 November: A PSNI officer was shot and wounded by the RIRA in [[Dungannon]], [[County Tyrone]].<ref name="BBC-PSNI-1211"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Real IRA admits shooting officer|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/7095156.stm|publisher=BBC|date=14 November 2007|accessdate=14 November 2007}}</ref> *16 December: The RIRA were blamed for a pipe bomb attack on a PSNI station in [[Strabane]], [[County Tyrone]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/7146621.stm|work=BBC News|title=Pipe bomb thrown at PSNI station|date=16 December 2007|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Breen |first=Stephen |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/dissidents-blamed-for-police-station-pipe-bomb-13502772.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120719051102/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/dissidents-blamed-for-police-station-pipe-bomb-13502772.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 July 2012 |title=Dissidents blamed for police station pipe bomb |publisher=BelfastTelegraph.co.uk |date=17 December 2007 |accessdate=10 October 2015 }}</ref>
==2008== *7 February: The RIRA announced that after a three-year period of reorganisation it was ready to "go back to war".<ref name="resumption">[http://www.nwipp-newspapers.com/UH/free/349259728115496.php "Mackey slams Provos as RIRA vows resumption of violence"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080616191412/http://www.nwipp-newspapers.com/UH/free/349259728115496.php |date=2008-06-16 }}, [http://www.nwipp-newspapers.com/UH/uhhomepage.php The Ulster Herald] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090927145701/http://www.nwipp-newspapers.com/UH/uhhomepage.php |date=2009-09-27 }}, 7 February 2008.</ref> *14 February: A former RIRA member, Andrew Burns, was killed by a small republican organisation, [[Óglaigh na hÉireann (Continuity Irish Republican Army splinter group)|Óglaigh na hÉireann]] in Doneyloop, [[County Donegal]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2008/feb/14/northernireland.northernireland|work=The Guardian|location=London, UK|title=Member of Real IRA found shot dead in churchyard|first=Henry|last=McDonald|date=14 February 2008|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.derryjournal.com/strabane/Burns-family-39deeply--.4051692.jp|title=Burns family|accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref> *12 May: The RIRA exploded a booby-trap bomb underneath the car of a PSNI officer in [[Spamount]], [[County Tyrone]]. The officer was pulled to safety by a passing motorist before the car was engulfed in flames.<ref>{{cite news|title=Officer hurt by booby-trap bomb|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/7397420.stm|publisher=BBC|date=13 May 2008|accessdate=22 May 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Murder bid admitted by Real IRA |author=Diana Rusk |url=http://www.irishnews.com/appnews/540/5860/2008/5/16/587806_345515892637Murderbid.html |publisher=''[[The Irish News]]'' |date=16 May 2008 |accessdate=22 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090210101742/http://www.irishnews.com/appnews/540/5860/2008/5/16/587806_345515892637Murderbid.html |archivedate=10 February 2009 |df= }}</ref> *9 September: The IMC blamed the RIRA for the discovery of an under vehicle explosive device under the car of a civilian in [[Lisburn]], [[County Antrim]]. It is believed the RIRA had mistaken the civilian for a member of the PSNI.<ref name="independentmonitoringcommission.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.independentmonitoringcommission.org/documents/uploads/Twenty-First%20Report.pdf |title=PremiumSale.com Premium Domains |publisher= |accessdate=22 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129105039/http://www.independentmonitoringcommission.org/documents/uploads/Twenty-First%20Report.pdf |archivedate=29 January 2016 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/7609827.stm|title=Bombers 'extend operational area'|date=11 September 2008|work=BBC News|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> *15 September: The IMC blamed the RIRA for the discovery of a 100 lb bomb in [[Jonesborough, County Armagh]].<ref name="independentmonitoringcommission.org"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/7616007.stm|title=Child touched 100lb beer keg bomb|date=15 September 2008|work=BBC News|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> *25 September: A man survived after being shot in the neck by the RIRA on the [[County Londonderry]]-[[County Donegal]] border.<ref name="stj">{{cite news|title=Pipe-bomb target previously shot by RIRA|work=The Irish News|date=29 October 2008}}</ref> The same man had been targeted in a [[pipe bomb]] attack on his home on 25 October, the RIRA did not claim responsibility for the attack, but security forces believe they were responsible for it.<ref name="stj"/> *19 November: The IMC blamed the RIRA for the discovery of a coffee jar bomb near a PSNI station in [[Belfast]].<ref name="independentmonitoringcommission.org"/><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/7738470.stm Coffee jar bomb found by police], bbc.co.uk; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref>
==2009== *7 March: [[2009 Massereene Barracks shooting]] - The RIRA shot dead two British Army soldiers (Patrick Azimkar and Mark Quinsey) as they collected a delivery outside [[Massereene Barracks]] in [[County Antrim]]. Two other soldiers and two civilian deliverymen were also wounded by gunfire.<ref>{{cite news|title='Real IRA was behind army attack'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/7930995.stm|publisher=BBC|date=7 March 2009|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref> Brian Shivers was convicted of the murders and other charges at Antrim Crown Court in January 2012, but following an appeal was cleared of all charges at retrial in May 2013.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-22405829 Shivers cleared of all charges on appeal], bbc.com; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref> John Paul Wootton and Brendan McConville were later convicted of the murders but have appealed.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Steven McCaffery |author2=Michael McHugh |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/dissidents-brendan-mcconville-and-john-paul-wootton-jailed-for-murder-of-stephen-carroll-7771031.html |title=Dissidents Brendan McConville and John Paul Wootton jailed for murder of Stephen Carroll |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=2012-05-21 |accessdate=2016-12-24}}</ref> *2 April: The RIRA claimed responsibility for carrying out a punishment shooting in [[Derry]] against a convicted rapist who was awaiting sentencing for raping a 15-year-old girl.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.londonderrysentinel.co.uk/news/Dissidents-claim-shooting.5138953.jp|title=Dissidents claim shooting|date=3 April 2009|publisher=Londonderry Sentinel|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> *5 July: [[Democratic Unionist Party]] (DUP) [[Member of Parliament|MP]] [[William McCrea (politician)|William McCrea]] was warned by police of a death threat from the RIRA.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/northern_ireland_politics/8135170.stm McCrea 'receives death threat'], bbc.co.uk; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref> *13 July: The RIRA was blamed for shooting at the PSNI in the [[Ardoyne]] area of North Belfast during heavy rioting after an Orange Order parade.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/8148955.stm|title=Real IRA blamed for Belfast riots|date=14 July 2009|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> *28 August: Armed RIRA members staged a roadblock in [[Meigh]], [[County Armagh]]. A PSNI patrol in an unmarked patrol vehicle spotted the group, but withdrew fearing that their presence would provoke a gun battle.<ref>[http://www.independent.ie/national-news/psni-steps-up-patrols-against-real-ira-threat-1873263.html PSNI steps up patrols against Real IRA threat], independent.ie; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref> *29 August: The IMC blamed the RIRA for the discovery of an improvised explosive near a school in [[Armagh]] town. The device was defused by the British Army.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/focus/2009/imc/index.pdf|work=The Irish Times|title=IMC blames RIRA for IED discovery|date=29 August 2009}}</ref> *5 September: The IMC blamed the RIRA for an attack on a man with iron bars and a sledge hammer in [[Strabane]], [[County Tyrone]].<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite web|url=http://www.independentmonitoringcommission.org/documents/uploads/23.%20Twenty-Third%20Report.pdf |title=IMC blames RIRA for attack on man in Strabane |accessdate=22 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129105039/http://www.independentmonitoringcommission.org/documents/uploads/23.%20Twenty-Third%20Report.pdf |archivedate=29 January 2016 |df= }}</ref> *17 September: The RIRA claimed responsibility for targeting an individual with an under vehicle explosive device in [[Belfast]]. It is believed the individual was employed by an engineering company with PSNI & Defence contracts.<ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/psni-chief-constable-baggott-pushes-on-with-normalisation-of-policing-14557233.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120721031633/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/psni-chief-constable-baggott-pushes-on-with-normalisation-of-policing-14557233.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 July 2012 |title=PSNI Chief Constable Baggott pushes on with normalisation of policing |accessdate=10 October 2015 }}</ref> *21 September: The RIRA claimed responsibility for two pipe-bomb attacks on the homes of family members of a PSNI officer in [[Derry]]. One of the devices exploded and destroyed a car.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/0912/1224254382515.html|title=Real IRA claims responsibility for Derry pipe bombs|date=12 September 2009|publisher=Irish Times|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> *7 October: The IMC blamed the RIRA for a hoax bomb alert outside a couthouse in [[Newry]], [[County Down]]. The alert caused massive disruption for both businesses and traffic in the city.<ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/8293988.stm|title=Newry alert an 'elaborate hoax'|date=7 October 2009|work=BBC News}}</ref> *8 October: RIRA members fired a volley of shots over the coffin of RIRA member John Brady in [[Strabane]], [[County Tyrone]]. Brady had died on 5 October in PSNI custody.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/foyle_and_west/8296322.stm|work=BBC News|title=Shots fired at cell death funeral|date=8 October 2009|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/oct/08/shots-fired-ira-man-funeral|work=The Guardian|location=London|title=Shots fired in salute at Real IRA man's funeral|first=Henry|last=McDonald|date=8 October 2009|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref> *10 October: The IMC blamed the RIRA for a hoax bomb alert at a courthouse in [[Strabane]], [[County Tyrone]]. Armed and masked men hijacked a taxi in the town, claiming they had left a device in the vehicle and then ordered the driver to abandon the vehicle outside the courthouse. The alert caused massive disruption.<ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/8300428.stm|title=Taxi driver told to bring 'bomb'|date=10 October 2009|work=BBC News}}</ref> *22 October: The RIRA claimed responsibility for a small explosion at a [[Territorial Army (United Kingdom)|British Territorial Army]] base in North Belfast which caused damage to the perimeter fence.<ref name="belfasttelegraph.co.uk">{{cite news|title=RIRA claims Belfast pipe bomb attack |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/real-ira-claims-pipebomb-attack-on-police-station-14665621.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130420075811/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/real-ira-claims-pipebomb-attack-on-police-station-14665621.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=20 April 2013 |accessdate=10 October 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.psni.police.uk/explosion_north_belfast_221009 |title=Explosion, North Belfast | Police Service of Northern Ireland |publisher=Psni.police.uk |date=2009-10-22 |accessdate=2015-10-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120829142105/http://www.psni.police.uk/explosion_north_belfast_221009 |archivedate=2012-08-29 |df= }}</ref> *19 November: The IMC blamed the RIRA for the discovery of a "crude wire mortar type device" in [[Armagh]] town.<ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/8367718.stm|title=Mortar 'designed to kill police'|date=19 November 2009|work=BBC News}}</ref> *21 November: The IMC blamed the RIRA for an attempted assassination of a serving PSNI officer in [[Garrison]], [[County Fermanagh]]. The operation was intercepted and a number of shots were exchanged between RIRA gunmen and police.<ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/8372713.stm|title=400lb bomb left at Policing Board|date=22 November 2009|work=BBC News}}</ref> *30 November: The IMC blamed the RIRA for failed pipe bomb attack on a PSNI station in [[Strabane]], [[County Tyrone]]. The Device which failed to explode was defused by the British army.<ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/8387654.stm "Pipe bomb thrown at PSNI station"], bbc.co.uk, 30 November 2009.</ref> *31 December: The RIRA claimed responsibility for a gun attack on [[Crossmaglen]] PSNI station, [[County Armagh]].<ref>[http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE5BU14O20091231 Shots fired at Crossmaglen (NI) police station], reuters.com; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/8490551.stm|work=BBC News|title=Real IRA 'attacked PSNI station'|date=1 February 2010|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref>
==2010== *24 January: The RIRA claimed responsibility for a gun attack on [[Crossmaglen]] PSNI station, [[County Armagh]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.4ni.co.uk/northern_ireland_news.asp?id=105673|accessdate=2 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605033550/http://www.4ni.co.uk/northern_ireland_news.asp?id=105673|title=Gun attack on Crossmaglen PSNI station|archivedate=5 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/8490551.stm|title=Real IRA 'fired shots at Bessbrook police station'|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref> *25 January: The RIRA claimed responsibility for the shooting death of a man in [[Cork (city)|Cork City]] in the Republic of Ireland. The RIRA claimed he was a drug dealer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/gardai-appeal--for-help-in-cork--murder-2029401.html|work=Irish Independent|first=Olivia|last=Kelleher|title=Gardaí appeal for help in Cork murder|date=24 January 2010}}</ref><ref>[http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/claim-real-ira-killed-corkman-443702.html Claim: Real IRA killed Corkman], breakingnews.ie; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref> *31 January: The RIRA claimed responsibility for a gun attack on a PSNI station in [[Bessbrook]], [[County Armagh]].<ref name="ReferenceA"/> *3 February: The RIRA claimed responsibility for throwing a pipe bomb at Oldpark PSNI station in [[Belfast]]. The device exploded causing damage to a perimeter fence of the station.<ref name="belfasttelegraph.co.uk"/> *22 February: The RIRA were blamed for detonating a 250 lb car bomb outside a courthouse in [[Newry]], [[County Down]]. The bombers issued a code-worded warning that the bomb would explode within 30 minutes, but it exploded 17 minutes later while police were evacuating the area. The courthouse guardhut was heavily damaged.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/real-ira-blamed-for-bomb-blitz-on-newry-courthouse-2076427.html|work=Irish Independent|first=Tom|last=Brady|title=Real IRA blamed for bomb blitz on Newry courthouse|date=24 February 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/8529541.stm|work=BBC News|title=Car bomb explodes at Newry courthouse|date=23 February 2010|accessdate=25 May 2010}}</ref> *24 February: The RIRA claimed responsibility for kidnapping and shooting dead Kieran Doherty. His body was found on the outskirts of [[Derry]], near the border with [[County Donegal]]; the RIRA said Doherty was a RIRA member who had been executed for drug dealing.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/foyle_and_west/8535731.stm Real IRA blamed for border murder], bbc.co.uk; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref><ref>[http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/issues/violence/deaths2010draft.htm Draft List of Deaths Related to the Conflict in 2010], cain.ulst.ac.uk; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref> *12 March: The PSNI claimed it had intelligence that Dale Moore, a Press Officer for [[Sinn Féin]] in Derry was under threat from the RIRA.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/foyle_and_west/8563846.stm Sinn Féin press officer allegedly receives death threat from RIRA], bbc.co.uk; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref> *19 March: The RIRA claimed responsibility for security alerts in [[Derry]]. At least three controlled explosions were carried out on suspect devices which had been left in various locations around the city.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/8575778.stm Real IRA say they caused Londonderry security alerts], bbc.co.uk, 19 March 2010.</ref> *21 March: The RIRA were blamed for a gun attack on PSNI officers dealing with a "suspect device" on the Belfast–Dublin railway line near [[Newry]], [[County Down]]. The device was found to be an "elaborate hoax".<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/8578622.stm Police fired on at railway alert], bbc.co.uk</ref><ref>[http://www.tribune.ie/news/home-news/article/2010/apr/04/dissident-republican-attacks-since-massereene RIRA attacks since Massereene], tribune.ie, 4 April 2010.</ref> *28 March: Four masked and armed men, claiming to be RIRA volunteers, hijacked a van on Coshquin Road in [[Derry]] and left it outside "Blackthorn Amusements" in [[Bridgend, County Donegal]]. The hijacking sparked a security alert which caused disruption to traffic in the area.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/foyle_and_west/8592493.stm Road open after Real IRA hijack], bbc.co.uk, 28 March 2010.</ref> *22 April: The IMC blamed the RIRA for a car bomb attack on a PSNI base in [[Newtownhamilton]], [[County Armagh]]. A telephoned warning was given an hour beforehand, but two civilians were hurt.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/8638902.stm|work=BBC News|title=Bomb explodes at police station|date=23 April 2010}}</ref> *23 April: The IMC blamed the RIRA for a pipe bomb attack on a house in [[Coalisland]], [[County Tyrone]]. It was claimed that the RIRA accused the occupants of being involved in drug-dealing and criminality.<ref name="IMC25">{{cite web|url=http://www.independentmonitoringcommission.org/documents/uploads/HC%20565%20pdf.pdf |title=IMC blames RIRA for pipe bomb attack in Coalisland |accessdate=22 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306063735/http://independentmonitoringcommission.org/documents/uploads/hc%20565%20pdf.pdf |archivedate= 6 March 2016 |df= }}</ref><ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/8638975.stm|title=Pipe bomb attack at house in town|date=23 April 2010|work=BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.u.tv/News/Coalisland-family-receive-dissident-threat/e31e2923-2b92-403f-a566-5d86087c2763 |title=U.TV - News from Northern Ireland |accessdate=22 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129194539/http://www.u.tv/News/Coalisland-family-receive-dissident-threat/e31e2923-2b92-403f-a566-5d86087c2763 |archivedate=29 November 2014 |df= }}</ref> *30 May: The IMC blamed the RIRA for a pipe bomb attack on a house at Windmill Court, [[Dungannon]], [[County Tyrone]]. The bomb was thrown through the kitchen window and caused considerable damage.<ref name="IMC25"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10193796|work=BBC News|title=Pipe bomb explodes in kitchen|date=30 May 2010}}</ref> *17 June: The IMC blamed the RIRA for an attempted van bomb attack on a PSNI station in [[Aughnacloy, County Tyrone|Aughnacloy]], [[County Tyrone]]. A telephoned warning was received and the 300 lb bomb was made safe by the British Army.<ref name="IMC25"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10347051|work=BBC News|title=300lb van bomb at Aughnacloy police station|date=18 June 2010}}</ref> *18 June: The IMC blamed the RIRA for an attempted pipe bomb attack on a PSNI station in [[Craigavon]], [[County Armagh]]. The device was made safe by the British Army.<ref name="IMC25"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10347650|work=BBC News|title=Pipe bomb thrown at police station in Craigavon|date=18 June 2010}}</ref> *22 June: The IMC blamed the RIRA for an attempted ambush on the [[Keady]]–[[Castleblayney]] road in County Armagh. Security forces were lured into the area by a fire and a bomb warning. A bomb with a command wire was found and made safe by the British Army.<ref name="IMC25"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10386597|work=BBC News|title=Police believe Keady fire and bomb alert linked|date=23 June 2010}}</ref> *2 July: The IMC blamed the RIRA for a gun attack on a PSNI station in [[Crossmaglen]], [[County Armagh]].<ref name="IMC25"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10496955|work=BBC News|title=Shots fired at Crossmaglen police station|date=3 July 2010}}</ref> *10 July: The IMC blamed the RIRA for exploding a bomb under a small stone bridge on Carrickrovaddy Road near [[Belleeks]], [[County Armagh]].<ref name="IMC25"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10588031|work=BBC News|title=South Armagh bomb 'designed to kill or injure police'|date=11 July 2010}}</ref> *26 July: The RIRA were blamed for a gun attack on the Players' Lounge pub on Fairview Strand, [[Dublin]]. A lone gunman entered the pub shortly after midnight and fired shots at a doorman. The doorman and two bystanders were wounded.<ref>[http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0726/fairview.html Dublin shooting may be linked to security dispute], rte.ie, 26 July 2010.</ref><ref>[http://www.independent.ie/national-news/three-men-injured-in-pub-shooting-2273005.html Three men injured in pub shooting], independent.ie; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref><ref>[http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/real-ira-behind-players-shooting-2280478.html Real IRA behind Players shooting], independent.ie; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref> *8 August: The IMC blamed the RIRA for planting a booby-trap bomb under a PSNI officer's car in [[Kilkeel]], [[County Down]]. It fell off the car and failed to explode.<ref name="IMC25"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-10902438|work=BBC News|title=Bomb at Catholic police officer's home in Kilkeel|date=8 August 2010}}</ref> *10 August: The IMC blamed the RIRA for planting a booby-trap bomb under a PSNI worker's car in [[Cookstown]], County Tyrone. The man worked as a civilian security guard at Cookstown PSNI base. It partially exploded but the man was unhurt.<ref name="IMC25"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-10924709|work=BBC News|title=Cookstown booby-trap bomb partially exploded|date=10 August 2010}}</ref> *4 October: The RIRA claimed responsibility for exploding a car bomb outside the Ulster Bank on Culmore Road in [[Derry]]. The bomb was more than 200 lb and exploded at 23:56, about an hour after a telephoned warning. Two PSNI officers were lightly hurt and the bank, a hotel and nearby shops were heavily damaged.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-11479594 Officers injured in Londonderry bombing], bbc.co.uk, 4 October 2010.</ref><ref>[http://www.derryjournal.com/journal/Real-IRA-claim-Derry-blast.6565898.jp Real IRA claim Derry blast], derryjournal.com; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref> *20 October: The RIRA claimed responsibility for shooting a man in the legs in [[Derry]]. The man was a convicted sex offender.<ref>[http://www.u.tv/News/Derry-man-shot-twice-in-each-leg/0994f093-6bc7-4442-b734-0ddf451d6f62 Derry man shot twice in each leg] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101023134641/http://www.u.tv/News/Derry-man-shot-twice-in-each-leg/0994f093-6bc7-4442-b734-0ddf451d6f62 |date=2010-10-23 }}, u.tv; 20 October 2010.</ref><ref>[http://www.derryjournal.com/journal/Real-IRA-shot-sex-offender.6599213.jp Real IRA shot sex offender], derryjournal.com; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref>
==2011== *18 January: The RIRA claimed responsibility for a blast bomb attack on the offices of UK City of Culture in Derry. The bomb caused minor damages to the offices.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.derryjournal.com/journal/Bomb-Anger.6694518.jp|title=Bomb Anger|publisher=Derry Journal|date=18 January 2011|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref> *16 February: The RIRA admitted responsibility for a viable pipe bomb device that was found outside a home in [[Magherafelt]], County Londonderry.<ref>[http://www.u.tv/News/Real-IRA-behind-pipe-bomb/f97c68a4-4bb0-4b45-a116-b0a158e7b035 'Real IRA' behind pipe bomb] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110218200653/http://www.u.tv/News/Real-IRA-behind-pipe-bomb/f97c68a4-4bb0-4b45-a116-b0a158e7b035 |date=2011-02-18 }}, u.tv; accessed 10 October 2015.</ref> *3 March: The RIRA claimed responsibility for a gun attack on a police patrol in Derry. A number of shots were fired as police investigated a report of a stolen car. Although no one was injured, one shot did hit the police car.<ref>[http://www.u.tv/News/Real-IRA-behind-Derry-gun-attack-/4295a1e4-6766-49f2-a28e-9bec172e73d6 Real IRA behind Derry gun attack] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110305192145/http://www.u.tv/News/Real-IRA-behind-Derry-gun-attack-/4295a1e4-6766-49f2-a28e-9bec172e73d6 |date=2011-03-05 }}, u.tv, 3 March 2011.</ref> *2 April: [[Murder of Ronan Kerr|PSNI officer Ronan Kerr]] was killed when a booby-trap bomb exploded under his car in Omagh, County Tyrone.
